comment.name: Sample_description
comment.value: Seeds were sown in soil, incubated at 4°C for 4 days in the dark, and then placed in constant conditions. Seeds were surface sterilised 10 minutes with 50% bleach, 0.2% SDS and rinsed 5 times with sterile water before sowed. Growth Room Commercial soil Levington M2 professional growing medium from The Scotts company (UK) Ltd (Paper Mill lane, Bramford, Ipswich, Suffolk, IP8 4BZ) lug-3 flowers show characteristic class A floral homeotic gene mutation defects ; sepals are staminoid/carpeloid, second whorl petals are either staminoid or absent and third-whorl stamens are fewer in number. The fourth whorl gynoecium exhibits unfused carpels with valves forming hornlike protrusions at the apex. These defects in floral organ identity and floral organ number were previously explained to be caused by ectopic expression of AG mRNA. AG independent defects are displayed by LUG mutants, and include abnormal carpel and ovule development, reduced female and male fertility, and narrower leaves and floral organs, suggesting that LUG has a wider role in floral development and a function in vegetative development. Further defects in vegetative development include first leaves variable in size between individuals, in the majority of the cases being smaller than wild type, possibly as a result of a retarded seedling development. Mature rosette leaves generally have longer petioles than wild type leaves. Plants are shorter with increased shoot branching, and develop between 6-10 lateral inflorescences from the rosette, which result in the development of many more inflorescences than wild type plants.

comment.name: Sample_description
comment.value: Seeds were sown in soil, incubated at 4°C for 4 days in the dark, and then placed in constant conditions. Seeds were surface sterilised 10 minutes with 50% bleach, 0.2% SDS and rinsed 5 times with sterile water before sowed. Growth Room Commercial soil Levington M2 professional growing medium from The Scotts company (UK) Ltd (Paper Mill lane, Bramford, Ipswich, Suffolk, IP8 4BZ) Wild type plants from the Landsberg erecta ecotype (Ler-0) have blunt siliques, upright stems, and bunched flowers; short petioles, usually upright stems and a compact inflorescence.

comment.name: Sample_description
comment.value: Seeds were sown in soil, incubated at 4°C for 4 days in the dark, and then placed in constant conditions. Seeds were surface sterilised 10 minutes with 50% bleach, 0.2% SDS and rinsed 5 times with sterile water before sowed. Growth Room Commercial soil Levington M2 professional growing medium from The Scotts company (UK) Ltd (Paper Mill lane, Bramford, Ipswich, Suffolk, IP8 4BZ) every two days with tap water lug-3 flowers show characteristic class A floral homeotic gene mutation defects ; sepals are staminoid/carpeloid, second whorl petals are either staminoid or absent and third-whorl stamens are fewer in number. The fourth whorl gynoecium exhibits unfused carpels with valves forming hornlike protrusions at the apex. These defects in floral organ identity and floral organ number were previously explained to be caused by ectopic expression of AG mRNA. AG independent defects are displayed by LUG mutants, and include abnormal carpel and ovule development, reduced female and male fertility, and narrower leaves and floral organs, suggesting that LUG has a wider role in floral development and a function in vegetative development. Further defects in vegetative development include first leaves variable in size between individuals, in the majority of the cases being smaller than wild type, possibly as a result of a retarded seedling development. Mature rosette leaves generally have longer petioles than wild type leaves. Plants are shorter with increased shoot branching, and develop between 6-10 lateral inflorescences from the rosette, which result in the development of many more inflorescences than wild type plants.
